Comment: >But we are fairly certain what the SC will decide, right?  No, because there's a fairly wide range of what SCOTUS can decide in Moore v. Harper. To keep the status quo, SCOTUS can rule state constitutions and laws can dictate how federal elections take place, which allow courts to redraw districts.  To take a LITTLE power away from the states, SCOTUS can rule that ONLY the legislature can draw the maps. So while courts can say they are illegal, they can't redraw them and can only make the legislature to redraw maps.  To take more power from the states, SCOTUS can rule that only state legislatures can decide district maps and the state judicial and executive branches have no say (essentially state law and constitutions have no say on how to draw congressional districts).   To take even MORE power from the states, SCOTUS can rule ALL federal election rules/laws/procedures are decided by the state legislature in accordance with federal law. So funding, districts, rules and procedures for voting locations, counting votes, etc. all are decided solely by the legislature not subject to the judiciary or executive branches of the state.  Where they will fall on that scale is unknown. I think the extremes are unlikely, but anything in-between is fair game.

Comment: Independent legislature theory isn't relevant to the question. It deals with whether the legislature can act alone - without the normal process of lawmaking and review including other branches of state government - rather than the power to appoint electors.  Even if the Independent Legislature doctrine was viewed favorably by the Supreme Court, it still wouldn't grant states to power to do what the original question asks because the Supreme Court has long ruled that election rules must be in place well before the election and cannot be changed on the fly.  Regardless of the outcome of the decision on the Independent Legislature Doctrine, states can still implement procedures that eliminate the popular vote for President in favor of legislative appointment if they so choose. The only relevance of ILD would be whether they could pass such a law without the assent of the governor and review of state courts.
